column5: Around 4000 years before Jesus, Adam's and Eve's first two sons were named Cain and Abel. Cain did not honour God, but Abel did. After God reproved Cain, Cain grew angry and killed his brother Abel.

column5: Abraham lived around 2000 years before Jesus. Because he believed God's promises, God declared him to be righteous. He also changed his name from Abram, which means Exalted Father, to Abraham, which means Father of many nations. Although his wife Sarai had no children, God promised that he would become an ancestor of many tribes and nations. And so he became the ancestor of all the Israelites and of other nations.

column4: Ibraam (W)
column5: Abram was the man whom God later called Abraham when he made a covenant with him. Abram's wife was called Sarai whom God later renamed Sarah. (The name Abram means High or Exalted Father.)

Absalom was the third son of King David. His mother was Maacah. He was his father's favourite son. His name means Father of peace. But he was not a peaceful man; he killed David's first son, Amnon, and later rebelled against David and overthrew him to become king. Absalom died when he and some men fought against David's soldiers.
Achaia was a Roman province in the southern part of Greece. The cities of Athens and Corinth were in it.

Achan was an Israelite man who stole gold, silver and clothes that belonged to the Lord. When the Lord identified him as the sinner, the Lord told Joshua and the Israelites to kill Achan and his whole family by throwing stones at them.  This was for the purpose of making the other people fear doing bad things lest they also suffer similar consequences.

column4: Aadama (W)
column5: Adam lived about 4000 years before Jesus. Adam was the first human being whom God created. Because Adam and his wife Eve disobeyed God, all human beings must die. The Bible calls Jesus the Second Adam, because Jesus gives eternal life to human beings.
column8: The concept of transmitted sin remains pure theology, whereas Scripture relates Adam to human death, even for those who have not sinned in the same way as did Adam.

column5: Adonijah was one of King David's younger sons. When David was old, Adonijah tried to become king, but David declared that Solomon must become king. (The name Adonijah means My Lord is the LORD.)
Adoni-Zedek was a Canaanite king of Jerusalem whom Joshua and the Israelites captured and put to death following a long battle.

Several men were named Ahijah. One was a prophet in northern Israel, another a king, and another a priest at Jerusalem. (The name Ahijah means Brother of the Lord.)
Ai was a Canaanite city full of people that worshipped pagan gods. God revealed a plan to Joshua that helped the Israelite army to capture Ai and destroy it as a sacrifice to God.

Ammon was a son of Abraham's nephew Lot. Ammon was born when Lot's daughter got him drunk and slept with him.  Ammon's descendants became the Ammonites who were sometimes enemies of Israel.  They worshipped idols.
Amnon was King David's first son. After Amnon raped David's daughter Tamar, her brother Absalom killed Amnon. (The name Amnon means Faithful.)

Three men were named Ananias in the New Testament: (1) a man in the early church in Jerusalem who died when he lied to God; (2) a Christian in Damascus who baptized Saul; (3) and a high priest in Jerusalem who opposed Jesus' apostles. (The name Ananaias means the Lord Answers.)
Andrew was a brother of Peter. They both became part of Jesus' 12 apostles. (The name Andrew means manly.)

column5: Angel is a Greek word that means messenger. An angel is a spirit being who serves God. When God sends a spirit with a message for humans, it can appear to be a human being and speak a human language. Evil spirits sometimes appear as angels.  When people die, they do not become an angel.

Apollos was a Jew from Alexandria, Egypt. As a man who spoke eloquently, he was competent in understanding the meaning of the Hebrew Scriptures, so was able to teach Chirstians in Greek-speaking cities.

column5: Aquila was husband of Priscilla. They were Jews from Rome who helped Paul to plant churches in Greece and in Syria. (The name Aquila means "eagle".)

column5: The Ark of the Covenant represented the presence of God for the people of Israel. It was a wooden box or chest covered with gold. The figures of two angels were on the top of it. This chest was kept in the Tabernacle, and later in the Temple, in the inner-most room known as the Holy of Holies.

column5: Artaxerxes was the 6th king of the Persian Empire 465-424 BC. He was grandson of Darius and son of Xerxes. (The name Artaxerxes means He rules with truth.)
Artemis, also called Diana, is the name of an Greek and Roman goddess whose idol many people worshipped in a province called Asia.
There were three men named Asaph in the Bible: One was Berachiah’s son whom King David chose to lead worship. This Asaph authored Psalms 50 and 73-83. His name means “gather”.
Two women were named Asenath. One was Joseph's Egyptian wife, and the other was Jacob's daughter Dina's daughter.

Ashtoreth was a carved idol used to worship a goddess (female god/deity) named Astart in pagan countries. Some Israelites sinned against the Lord by making Ashtoreth idols, which they often set along side idols of a god (male deity) named Ba'al.

column5: Wherever Christians come together to honor Jesus and show love one to another, they form a temporary gathering or a permanent assembly.
Assyria was a powerful nation that invaded northern Israel in the year 738 before Christ. Assyrian soldiers treated their enemies cruelly.

Athalia was an evil queen who tried to kill Joash and stop him from being king.  She was daughter or grand-daughter of King Omri. She married king Jehoram of Judah. After he died, she tried to murder all of his sons.

Athens was the largest city of ancient Greece. Athenians are people who live in or are from Athens.  The city was a place known for higher education and idol worship. The apostle Paul visited there on one of his missionary journeys (Acts 17)
Baal is the name of an evil god at whose idol many nations used to worship. God sometimes had to punish the Israelites, after they would forsake him to worship Baal.
column8: Ba'al is very well known in cuneiform texts, a kind of international deity with many local idols.

column5: Babylon is the name of an ancient city, founded about 3000 years before Jesus. She became a very powerful nation and the kings of Babylon conquered many other countries. When the Babylonian army captured Israel, they took many Israelites to dwell in Babylon for seventy years. The people of this nation acted very badly and disobeyed and rebelled against God. Therefore, the name is sometimes used symbolically to refer to an evil place, as Peter called Rome "Babylon." It can also refer to a place that God will destroy in the future, just as He destroyed the historical city. In the book of Revelation, Babylon will be completely destroyed.
column8: Actually, 70 years serving the kings of Babylon, part of which was spent in captivity.

column5: Balaam lived around 1500 years before Jesus. Balaam was a pagan prophet who, to get money, pretended to speak for God. God ordered the Israelites to kill Balaam.  One time God spoke to Balaam through his donkey.
column8: In that era, pagan prophets not only spoke for the gods, but were believed to have persuasive power over gods. Thus, Balaam sold his services as one who could manipulate Yahweh.

column4: to pass (a person) under/through water (D); dip in water (W); (to symbolize death to an old life and the start of a new life); initiate / initiation; cause to have oneself bathed (becoming followers of Jesus the True Chief)(G); baptais (K);
column5: Baptize is a Greek word that means to wash in water or to dip in water. Jews and some pagans baptize as part of their worship. John baptized Jews who were waiting for Messiah to come. Jesus commanded his apostles to go make disciples by baptizing and teaching them. Christians baptize those who put their trust in Jesus.
column8: A symbolic initiation in/with water that Jesus commanded for those who repent of their sins to become Christians. There are many ways in which to baptize. To dip under/ bury in water and bring back up/out to signify death to old life and resurrected to new life, a new identity. There are a series of baptisms in the Bible: God brought Noah through the water to start a new life after the judgment flood. God (via Moses) rescused Israel from their slavery in Egypt and brought them through the water of the big sea to start a new life trusting him in the wilderness. God (via Joshua) led the new generation of Israel through the Jordan River to begin a new life obeying God in a new land. John dipped people in the waters of the Jordan River who were repenting from their sins and getting prepared for Kingdom life. Jesus went down into the waters of the Jordan River to be baptized by John and came out the other side to go into the wilderness for 40 days to show that he was re-playing Israel as the new Israel but doing it rightly, faithfully, in full obedience to God. Jesus commanded people who believe in him to be put under water to show that they have died and been buried to their old life of rebelling against God and have been raised up to a new life with a new identity as God's children.

column5: Barabbas was the name of the criminal whom Pilate freed when the Jewish crowd was demanding Jesus' death. Interestingly, Bar-Abbas meaning "son of the father" was set free while Jesus the Son of Father God was crucified.
Barak was the fourth judge in Israel, before they had kings. Barak led the Israelites in war, defeating their enemies.

Barnabas was one of the first Christians at Jerusalem. He brought Paul to meet the first apostles, and he later brought Paul to Antioch (in Syria) to make disciples. He and Paul also went together on mission to start new churches of new believers. (The name Barnabas means Son of Encouragement).

Bathsheba was the beautiful wife of Uriah, a soldier in king David's army. She once took a bath outside where king David saw her bathing. Later they slept together. David caused Uriah to die in battle, then married Bathsheba. God punished David for his sins and caused his first child with Bathsheba to die. Bathsheba's son Solomon became king after David. (The name Bathsheba means Daughter of Promise or Oath.)

column5: A bear is a very large, strong, hairy beast that dwells in forests. Bears are dangerous, have sharp teeth and long claws, can climb trees, and can kill people. Bears eat almost anything. When an adult bear stands up on two legs, it is taller than a man.
Beelzebul is another name for the evil god Baal. Some folk believe him to be chief over evil spirits.

Beersheba was a water well and eventually a city in ancient Israel. Beersheba marked the southernmost boundary of cultivated land in Israel. It is the place where Abraham made a treaty with the Philistine king Abimelech. Be’er-sheva or Beersheba means “treaty well”.
Belshazzar was the last king of Babylon. He died in 539 BC when the Persians conquered Babylon. (The name Belshazzar means the god Bel preserves the king.)
Benjamin lived around 2000 years before Jesus. Benjamin was the youngest of Jacob's twelve sons. Thus, Benjamin was the ancestor of one of the twelve tribes of the Israelites.
column8: The term Jew (Judean) does not appear in the Hebrew Scripture until the time of the Babylonian captivity.

column5: Bethel is the name of a city in the central part of the land of Israel, originally called Luz. The book of Genesis tells of Jacob meeting God near that town, so he renamed that place Bethel, which means God's house.

Bethlehem is the name of a city a few kilometers south of Jerusalem in the region that was known as Judah. King David and his ancestors lived there, and Jesus was born there. (The name Bethlehem means house of bread.)

The Old Testament contains the history of God's relationship with the people of Israel. The New Testament tells the history of Jesus Christ and the teachings of his followers.

Boaz was a wealthy Israelite farmer who allowed the poor to glean grain that his harvesters left behind. He was a relative of Naomi's dead husband, so he married Ruth, Naomi's widowed daughter-in-law. Thus, he became an ancestor of King David and of Jesus.

Book can mean a part of the Bible that has a name or title, such as Book of Isaiah. Book is also a symbol of God's memory.

Bread is a basic food throughout the world that people eat every day. God sent something like bread called manna to the Israelites after they left Egypt while they were in the wilderness. Jesus described himself as the "bread of life", because he gives eternal life to those who trust in him.

Caesar was the title that the Romans gave to their highest ruler (instead of calling them "king" or "president"). Each Caesar was the emperor or ruler over all the territories that Rome conquered.

There were two towns called Caesarea, both named in honor of the Roman emperors who were called Caesar, as the name means King's Town. One was on the Mediterranean Sea coast to the northwest of Jerusalem. It was built by the Romans. The other, known as Caesarea Philippi, was located north of the Sea of Galilee and was built by King Herod.

Around 4000 years before Jesus, Adam's and Eve's first two sons were named Cain and Abel. Cain was a farmer who gave an offering of his crops to God. However, God was not pleased with it and he favored Abel's offering over Cain's. Because Cain did not honour God correctly, God reproved him. So Cain grew angry and killed his brother Abel.

Caleb was one of the twelve spies whom Moses sent to observe the land of Canaan, the land Promised to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. He and Joshua were the only two spies that believed the Israelites could conquer the Canaanites. God rewarded these two men for their faith and their bravery in battle.

They are 'saints', that is, holy ones, those who belong to God. They are 'believers', that is, those who have faith in Jesus. They are 'disciples', that is, those who obey Jesus' commandments. column5: Circumcision is a ritual cut made on a boy's or a man’s penis which removes the foreskin from the end of the penis. God commanded circumcision for all Israelite men or baby boys as a signal that they were loyal to God's Old Covenant. In the New Testament, physical circumcision is no longer required to make known relationship or loyalty to God. Rather, it is used in a figurative way to explain how Christ has cut away the believer's fleshly (sinful) nature to give a new, righteous nature (Col. 2:11-13; Rom. 4:11; 1 Cor 7:18).  Also, baptism is now the sign of our loyalty to God's New Covenant.

column4: clear (K); clean (R);
column5: In Jewish culture, clean did not mean washed, and unclean did not mean dirty. Rather, clean and unclean were ceremonial categories. Clean meant things or actions that God allows/permits. Clean things or persons may serve God in his tent or his temple. But God forbids unclean things or persons. Unclean things must be kept away from God’s tent or temple. Some unclean things or persons may be made clean by washing with water, by offering a sacrifice, by sprinkling them with blood, or by a message from God. You may translate clean by ‘ceremonially pure, acceptable, or allowed’. You may translate unclean by ‘ceremonially impure, unacceptable, or forbidden’. (Deuteronomy 14 talks about clean and unclean animals.)  For those who believe in Jesus, his blood cleanses them from all sin and defilement through their faith in him.

The concubine did not have the same status as a regular wife, and her children usually would not receive an inheritance like the children of a regular wife would.

Israel is a name in the Bible used to refer to different people and places. It was first used by God's angel when he renamed Jacob, the grandson of Abraham, as Israel. Then his descendents became a nation that was called Israel, and those people are called Israelites. After 400 years in Egypt, they moved to the land of Canaan and lived there, so the territory became known as Israel. After King Solomon's death, the nation divided in two; the southern kingdom was known by the name of the tribe of Judah, and the northern kingdom was known as Israel. In our day, Israel is once again used as the name of the nation in that land.

Jabin was a Canaanite king who lived in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera, who cruelly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years. After the Israelites prayed to the Lord, they defeated Jabin's army and killed him.

Jacob lived about 1850 years before Jesus. He was a son of Isaac and grandson of Abraham. After Jacob wrestled with an angel from God, the angel gave him a new name, Israel. Israel's twelve sons became the ancestors of the twelve tribes of Israel. Thus, the Israelites are sometimes called the House of Jacob.

Jael was the wife of Heber the Kenite. They lived in Israel but the Kenites were at peace with the Canaanites. When Sisera the Canaanite army commander fled from the Israelite army, he took refuge in Jael's tent. She welcomed him in as a friend, but then she killed him as he slept. (The name Jael means "The Lord is God".)

Jehoiada, the high priest of Jerusalem's temple in the kingdom of Judah, served during the reigns of King Ahaziah, Queen Athaliah, and King Joash. When Joash was a baby, Jehoiada's wife saved him from Queen Athaliah's plot to kill him. Jehoiada helped lead a revolt that resulted in Queen Athaliah's overthrow and death.

Jephthah lived about 1700 years before Jesus during the time of the judges. He was a mighty warrior and became the leader of the Israelite's army, leading it to victory over the Ammonites. He made a rash vow to God and subsequently had to sacrifice his daughter in a burnt offering.

Jeremiah lived around 600 years before Jesus, before and during the time when Israel was destroyed by Babylon. God sent him to call the Israelites to repent of their disobedience. During 40 years he warned them that the Bablonians would come and capture Jerusalem and take them into captivity for 70 years, but they did not repent. Jeremiah is known as the "weeping prophet" and he wrote the book of Lamentations.

Jericho was the name of a strong, walled city in Canaan. It was the first city that Joshua and the Israelites came to in Canaan. Two Israelite men were sent to spy in the city. A woman who lived there, named Rahab, helped them escape. Joshua led Isreal to fight against the city, and God caused the walls of Jericho to fall down. With God's miraculous help they defeated it.

After King Solomon died, his kingdom was divided in two. Jeroboam became king over the northern part, which they called Israel. Jeroboam told the people to stop going to Jerusalem to worship God, and he told them to worship by bowing to idols that looked like a bull. He also made himself to be a priest. These actions displeased the Lord. Jeroboam was a wicked king.

Jerusalem is a city king David captured and made Israel's capital city. (The name Jerusalem means Peace City.)  After David, his son King Solomon built a temple for God at Jerusalem. For 1000 years, Jerusalem city remained the central place of worship for Jews. Another name for Jerusalem is Mount Zion, because it is located on a mountain. Jerusalem has been destroyed and rebuilt several times.
Jesse was the father of King David, who was an ancestor of Jesus Christ. In the Old Testament, the prophet Isaiah had written that the Messiah or Christ would be a descendant of Jesse and of David.

column5: Sabbath is a Hebrew word meaning rest or cease from work. After creating the world, God (and later the Law of Moses) decreed the seventh day of each week to be a Sabbath day uniquely for rest, not for doing any normal or hard work. Feasts and festivals were also Sabbath days. In Jesus time, the Jews had added many more rules against activity on Sabbath days. Jesus angered the Jewish leaders because he sometimes broke those rules. Israelites offered three kinds of sacrifices: 1) Purification sacrifices. Since human beings pollute their community with everything that comes from their body, they had to offer bloody sacrifices to purify Yahweh's tabernacle (tent), so that he could continue to dwell amongst them. 2) Worship sacrifices. Just as people must pay taxes and tribute to chiefs and kings, so humans had to offer up burnt sacrifices to honour Yahweh, along with their prayers and petitions on behalf of their community and of themselves. 3) Thanksgiving sacrifices. Both the community and individuals offered sacrifices in thanks and praise to Yahweh who had provided all that they needed, or after he had answered their prayers. However, there was no sacrifice to remove the guilt of personal sins and crimes. Much later, Jesus would offer himself as a sacrifice, when he was crucified, so that God forgives the sins of those who repent and trust in Jesus. (Adapted from Lexham Bible Dictionary.)
